Line 21: Line 21:
Derivatives of ash are installed as the default shell (<tt>/bin/sh</tt>) on [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]], [[DragonFly BSD]] and [[Minix]]. ash is also fairly popular in [[embedded Linux]] systems; its code was incorporated into the [[BusyBox]] catch-all executable often employed in this area. [[Debian]]'s version of ash is known as [[Debian Almquist shell|Debian Almquist Shell (dash)]].
Derivatives of ash are installed as the default shell (<tt>/bin/sh</tt>) on [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]], [[DragonFly BSD]] and [[Minix]]. ash is also fairly popular in [[embedded Linux]] systems; its code was incorporated into the [[BusyBox]] catch-all executable often employed in this area. [[Debian]]'s version of ash is known as [[Debian Almquist shell|Debian Almquist Shell (dash)]].
â
Some [[Linux]] distributions also use a derivative of ash as the default shell, although [[Bash]] (Bourne Again Shell) is more popular. [[Ubuntu]] [[Symbolic link|symlinks]] <tt>/bin/sh</tt> to the dash shell for faster script execution, but keeps [[Bash]] as the default login shell.
+
Some [[Linux]] distributions also use a derivative of ash as the default shell, although [[Bash]] (Bourne Again Shell) is more popular. [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] [[Symbolic link|symlinks]] <tt>/bin/sh</tt> to the dash shell for faster script execution, but keeps [[Bash]] as the default login shell.
